question_text: In solar-combustion hybrids using chemical looping combustion (CLC), how does the endothermic reduction of metal oxides with solar thermal energy enhance both CO₂ capture efficiency and energy storage density?
standard_answer: In solar-chemical looping combustion (Hy-Sol-CLC), solar thermal energy drives the endothermic reduction of metal oxides (e.g., MeO → Me + 1/2 O₂) in the fuel reactor, which separates the oxidation and reduction steps. This process inherently captures CO₂ by avoiding direct fuel-air contact, as the fuel reduces the metal oxide, producing a concentrated CO₂ stream after condensation. Solar energy input elevates the reduction temperature, increasing reaction kinetics and conversion efficiency, while the exothermic oxidation with air regenerates the metal oxide, releasing heat for power cycles. The integration enhances energy storage density by storing solar energy chemically in the reduced metal and sensibly in the solid carrier, combining latent and sensible heat. This dual storage mitigates solar intermittency, as the stored chemical energy can be dispatched on demand. The synergy reduces infrastructure costs by using the same components for CO₂ capture and solar storage, and the high-temperature operation (up to 1000°C) improves thermodynamic efficiency compared to standalone systems.

original_text.1: Chemical looping combustion uses an oxygen carrier to oxidise the fuel (and reduce the carrier), following which the metal particle is oxidised in air. This approach avoids direct contact between the fuel and air to achieve inherent CO₂ capture.
original_text.2: Furthermore, the fuel reactor can potentially also be used to provide energy dense storage of solar energy, combining both chemical and sensible heat.
